Core Problem Statement: College students often miss assignment deadlines because due dates are scattered across multiple sources — originating from professors, teaching assistants, and departments through LMS platforms, emails, WhatsApp groups, notice boards, and in-class announcements. There’s no single dashboard, causing confusion, stress, and last-minute work or regret.
Target Audience (be specific): College students, professionals, and anyone managing multiple deadlines.
The “Cost of the Problem” headline metri: Each user loses about ₹200/month and ~90 hours per year due to disorganization. For 5,000 users, that’s roughly ₹1.2 crore in wasted productivity and over 4,50,000 total hours lost annually — a gap Deadline Desk directly aims to close.
Key interview insights (3–4 points):
Most respondents rely on WhatsApp groups or LMS portals for deadlines — making it easy to miss updates.
Over 70% admitted they’ve missed or almost missed a deadline or meeting due to scattered information.
Respondents want a single, automated dashboard that gathers all tasks from multiple sources.
Many prefer a calendar-style interface with smart reminders over plain to-do lists.
Most powerful customer quote (with role):
“Deadlines come from so many places — WhatsApp, mail, College portal — there’s no proper information until the last minute, and it’s impossible to keep up with everything.”
— Second Year College Student
Market Size — TAM (describe + number):
TAM (Total Addressable Market): All university students and working professionals in India. India has ~38 million higher education students (as per AISHE report).
Add ~50 million working professionals who handle regular meetings and deadlines.
TAM ≈ 88 million potential users.
Market Size — SAM (describe + number): Tech-savvy students and early-career professionals (urban areas) with access to digital tools like Google Calendar, LMS, and WhatsApp. Estimation: Approx. 25% of the TAM actively uses digital productivity or calendar tools. SAM ≈ 22 million users.

With around 5,000–10,000 potential users on campus (including students, clubs, and faculty), this forms a practical and achievable target group for testing, feedback, and early adoption before expanding to nearby institutions.

Each missed or late submission may lead to a grade penalty or loss of marks (5–10%), and causes significant stress and rework.  Students typically spend 1–2 hours per week searching for deadlines scattered across WhatsApp, emails, and LMS platforms.  Missed deadlines can also impact academic performance, attendance, and reputation in group work or internships. Data Sources:  Informal survey and feedback from classmates (5–6 students over a 7-day testing period) as described in the prototype plan.  Reference to actual course workload and digital communication patterns from college LMS, email notifications, and notice boards.  Simple Formula Used:  Estimated Time Lost per Student = Avg. weekly search time × Weeks per semester Estimated Time Lost per Student=Avg. weekly search time×Weeks per semester Potential Grade Impact = Missed assignments × Penalty per assignment Potential Grade Impact=Missed assignments×Penalty per assignment
How people cope now (list 3–4 current so:
1) Use manual tracking methods such as notebooks, sticky notes, or phone reminders.
2) Add tasks manually in Google Calendar or the phone’s built-in calendar.
3) Scroll through WhatsApp messages or LMS platforms to find deadlines.
4) Depend on friends or group chats to be reminded of upcoming due dates.
Why those fail (one sentence per solutio:
1) Manual methods are easy to forget, misplace, or overlook, especially during busy weeks.
2) Calendar tools require manual entry and don’t sync automatically with LMS or chats.
3) Searching chats or LMS posts is inefficient. Deadlines get buried under unrelated messages.
4) Relying on others is unreliable and inconsistent, as peers may also forget or miss updates.
The identified gap (white space): There’s no unified, automated system that collects deadlines and meetings from multiple sources (LMS, WhatsApp, email) and organizes them in one dashboard with smart reminders and sync which is affordable, reliable, and easy to use.
Important (quantified impact): Scaled Impact: For just 1% of our target market (6M users), the problem wastes ~1.25 billion hours and ~$35 billion annually. Human Impact: Surveys show that over 80% of students and professionals report high levels of stress and anxiety directly linked to the fear of missing deadlines.
Profitable (clear revenue or WTP signal): The financial opportunity is substantial, even with a conservative approach. Our SOM (Year 1): 50,000 users (mix of students & professionals). Business Model: Freemium (Free base product, Premium subscription for advanced features). Conversion Assumption: 5% of users convert to a premium plan priced at $5 per month ($60/year). Annual Recurring Revenue (ARR): 50,000 users × 5% conversion = 2,500 paying customers. 2,500 customers × $60/year = $150,000 ARR in Year 1.
Solvable (team capacity): This is a software and data integration problem, which is highly solvable with modern technology. Technologically Feasible: We can use available tools such as Tesseract.js or Google Vision API for OCR extraction and the Google Calendar API for synchronization. The core function — aggregating and displaying deadlines from multiple sources into a unified dashboard — is a well-understood software challenge, implementable using the MERN stack. Scalable Architecture: The solution can be built as a cloud-based web and mobile app, enabling rapid scaling for students, departments, or institutions without requiring significant physical infrastructure.
Contextual (why you’re the right team): We are the primary users experiencing this pain point daily. User Empathy & Insight: As students and former interns, we live this chaos of juggling university LMS, group project WhatsApp chats, and internship tasks on Slack. This deep, firsthand experience ensures we build a solution that actually works for the user, not just one that looks good on paper. Direct Market Access: We have immediate access to a large pilot group of students (our university) and young professionals (our networks) for rapid testing, feedback, and initial user acquisition.
TIPSC Cohesion (one-sentence summary): Deadline Desk is a timely, student-driven, and technically feasible solution that tackles the growing chaos of scattered digital deadlines through smart integration, real user insight, and scalable cloud-based design to create lasting impact.
Proposed solution direction (one paragra: A smart web dashboard that automatically collects all deadlines, meetings, and tasks from sources like LMS, WhatsApp, and email into one clean interface. Users can add deadlines manually or upload PDFs/notices, with OCR extracting due dates and titles automatically. Integrated with Google Calendar and smart reminders (including voice alerts), it helps users stay on top of every task with minimal effort.
Key value proposition: Deadline Desk eliminates the need to manually track, or cross-check deadlines scattered across multiple platforms. By combining automation through OCR and smart integrations with personalized reminders and cross-platform synchronization, it helps users stay organized, save time, and reduce stress. The platform ensures no deadline slips through the cracks while boosting reliability, focus, and overall productivity for students and professionals alike.
Next step with support (e.g., pilot plan: With Support, Our Next Step Would Be: To develop a working pretotype of Deadline Desk and run a 2-week pilot within our college to test real user behavior, gather feedback, and measure how much it reduces missed deadlines. Based on results, we’ll refine the UI, improve automation (OCR and sync), and prepare for wider rollout to nearby institutions.
rationale: Urgent need due to fragmented digital communication in education.
Directly impacts student success, grades, and mental well-being.
Technically feasible, but integrating diverse, unstructured data is the challenge.

Core Problem Statement: Our campus faces poor recycling participation due to the absence of a system that tracks and rewards students for their efforts. This lack of motivation and recognition leads to improper waste segregation, low engagement, and increased plastic waste across the campus
Target Audience (be specific): College students and hostel residents, along with campus administration and housekeeping teams involved in waste management.
The “Cost of the Problem” headline metri: ₹20–25 lakh/year spent on waste disposal : Based on available information, the estimated annual cost of unmanaged waste at PES University's Banashankari campus
Key interview insights (3–4 points):
1.Students are aware of recycling but rarely segregate waste due to convenience issues.

2.Hostel and canteen staff find monitoring waste segregation manually very time-consuming.

3.Incentives (rewards, recognition) significantly increase student willingness to participate.

4.QR-based tracking and app integration would make the process more engaging and transparent.
Most powerful customer quote (with role): "If I can earn points for recycling that I can redeem in the cafeteria, I’d definitely do it every day." – , 2nd Year Engineering

Calculation Notes:  Assumptions:  Average waste per student per day = 0.5 kg  Student population = 25,000  Waste disposal cost = ₹5/kg  Operating 365 days/year  Formula:  Annual Waste Disposal Cost = Number of Students × Waste per Student per Day × Disposal Cost per kg × 365 Annual Waste Disposal Cost=Number of Students×Waste per Student per Day×Disposal Cost per kg×365  Calculation:  25 , 000 × 0.5  kg × ₹ 5 × 365 = ₹ 22 , 812 , 500 ≈ ₹ 22.8  lakh/year 25,000×0.5 kg×₹5×365=₹22,812,500≈₹22.8 lakh/year  Interpretation: The campus spends ~₹22–23 lakh annually on waste disposal, part of which could be mitigated with an effective recycling + reward system.
How people cope now (list 3–4 current so:
1.Manual segregation by hostel/canteen staff
2.General awareness campaigns and posters
3.Student-led drives by sustainability clubs
4.Traditional waste bins with no tracking
Why those fail (one sentence per solutio:
1.Manual segregation is time-consuming and prone to errors.
2.Awareness campaigns don’t sustain daily student behavior.
3.Student drives reach only a small fraction of the campus.
4.Traditional bins don’t provide feedback or incentives.
The identified gap (white space): There is no automated, incentivized, and trackable system to encourage daily recycling across high-traffic campus areas.
Important (quantified impact): Unmanaged waste costs the campus ~₹22.8 lakh/year and contributes to low recycling rates, with only ~20% of waste being segregated.
Profitable (clear revenue or WTP signal): Our SOM (PES Banashankari, 25,000 students) represents a potential market of ₹22–23 lakh/year in waste management savings and a monetizable rewards ecosystem
Solvable (team capacity): The problem is solvable because existing off-the-shelf QR code and app platforms can be integrated with simple reward tracking, and student volunteers and sustainability clubs can manage monitoring and engagement
Contextual (why you’re the right team): We are hostel and campus students, directly experiencing the challenges and with access to student clubs and facilities, enabling easy piloting and adoption.
TIPSC Cohesion (one-sentence summary): A tech-enabled, reward-driven recycling system can cut costs, improve sustainability, and engage students now, leveraging our team’s skills and campus access.
Proposed solution direction (one paragra: We propose a QR-based recycling and reward system that encourages students and staff to segregate and recycle waste in high-traffic campus areas. By scanning QR codes on bins, participants can track their recycling activity and earn points redeemable for small incentives, fostering engagement and sustained behavioral change while improving campus waste management.
Key value proposition: Motivates eco-friendly behavior, reduces unmanaged waste costs, and leverages student participation to create a cleaner, more sustainable campus environment.

Collect usage and reward redemption data over 4–6 weeks to evaluate participation, measure waste reduction, and refine the system before scaling campus-wide.

Core Problem Statement: Our campus's confusing layout of disconnected blocks, linked by a maze of tunnels and varied floor connections, causes significant disorientation and stress for everyone navigating it.
Target Audience (be specific): New students (freshers), visiting parents & guests, and even long-term students.
The “Cost of the Problem” headline metri: "Causes daily frustration and wastes an estimated 10-15 minutes per trip, leading to missed events and significant anxiety."
Key interview insights (3–4 points):
* The primary source of confusion is the non-intuitive connection between blocks via basements, tunnels, and lifts. 
* The problem is persistent; 2nd and 3rd-year students still report getting lost or feeling unsure when navigating to less-frequented areas. 
* "Hotspot" areas like auditoriums (with separate entries/exits) and main halls are major points of frustration. * The lack of clear, centralized information creates high levels of stress, especially before exams or important meetings.
Most powerful customer quote (with role): "Even after a year here, I still get confused. The other day, I was trying to find an auditorium exit and ended up in a completely different block. It’s embarrassing and incredibly frustrating." - 2nd Year Student
Market Size — TAM (describe + number): ~4.3 crore students enrolled in Indian Higher Education Institutions (HEIs).
Market Size — SAM (describe + number): Students, staff, and visitors at all large, multi-building campuses in India.
Market Size — SOM (describe + number): The [~5,000] students, faculty, and regular visitors on our campus who are directly affected.
Cost of the Problem — calculation notes: Formula: (Affected Population) x (Avg. Time Lost per Week) x (Academic Weeks) = Total Time Lost Breakdown:  * Affected Population (SOM): 5,000 students & guests  * Avg. Time Lost per Student/Week: 30 minutes  * Active Academic Weeks: 32 weeks * Total Annual Time Wasted = (5,000 x 30 min x 32 weeks) / 60 * = 80,000 Hours Lost Per Year
How people cope now (list 3–4 current so:
* Inefficient Workaround 1: Constantly asking seniors, staff, or security guards for directions. 
* Inefficient Workaround 2: Using static, 2D campus maps (PDFs or physical boards).
 * Inefficient Workaround 3: Trial and error—wandering around until they find the right location. 
* Existing "Solution": Using Google/Apple Maps.
Why those fail (one sentence per solutio:
* Asking People: Unreliable; even seniors often don't know all the "maze-like" routes. 
* Static Maps: Fail to show the 3D complexity of tunnels, basements, and lift connections.
 * Trial and Error: Extremely time-consuming and the primary source of frustration. 
* Google/Apple Maps: Their service stops at the building's entrance; they have no indoor data.
The identified gap (white space): "There is no integrated, interactive navigation tool that understands the *true 3D layout* of our campus. Users need a solution that can route them not just *to* a building, but *through* the complex tunnels, floors, and lifts *inside* it."
Important (quantified impact): The problem has a massive quantified impact: it wastes an estimated 80,000 productive hours annually on our campus and is a direct source of significant stress for over 85% of students.
Profitable (clear revenue or WTP signal): Our SOM of 5,000+ users represents a clear B2B market by offering a subscription-based digital solution to the university administration, which is highly scalable to other campuses (our SAM).
Solvable (team capacity): This is a digital problem solvable with technology. Our team's skills in [App Development/CSE], [UX/UI Design], and [Data Mapping] are a direct match for building a functional indoor navigation prototype.
Contextual (why you’re the right team): We are the right team because we are the users. We experience this frustration daily, giving us a deep, personal understanding of the problem and direct access to the student body for rapid testing.
TIPSC Cohesion (one-sentence summary): The urgent (T) and significant (I) problem of campus disorientation is a prime opportunity for our team, as we possess the direct user context (C) and technical skills (S) to build a highly scalable and profitable (P) B2B navigation solution.
Proposed solution direction (one paragra: We propose an interactive web application, "CampusNav," that serves as a high-fidelity, indoor navigation system. This platform will provide real-time, step-by-step directions that accurately map the complex maze of tunnels, lifts, basements, and multi-floor connections.
Key value proposition: Our solution provides a single, reliable source of truth for navigation. It guarantees accurate, end-to-end routing (from any room to any room), directly eliminating time wasted in trial-and-error wandering and removing the significant stress caused by disorientation.
Next step with support (e.g., pilot plan: Develop an MVP (Minimum Viable Prototype) of the web app focused on mapping one high-traffic 'hotspot' (e.g., Main Block to the Auditorium) and run a 2-week pilot with 50+ students to validate routing accuracy and gather feedback.
rationale: A persistent, not urgent, quality-of-life issue on campus.
Technically very solvable with modern indoor mapping and AR.
Limited profitability; relies on university funding, not direct users.
